awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Restoring Function in Chronic Venous Insufficiency: Unraveling the Structural-Mechanics of Venous Valve Tissues
awd_abstract_narration:
1553430
Huang

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is a debilitating vascular disease with a prevalence estimated to be twice as high in women; risk increases with pregnancy, age, and occupations involving standing. CVI is considered a disabling condition by the US Social Security Administration; however, increasing prevalence has not been met with commensurate increases in rehabilitation research. For the first time, this CAREER project will provide a detailed compositional, structural and biaxial mechanical characterization of venous valve leaflet, sinus and associated vein tissues. Thus, this research will fill a critical gap in the basic science of venous valves, as well as serve as a springboard for innovation, informing approaches to the treatment of CVI. This CAREER project will engage a diverse range of groups: high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, postdocs, underrepresented groups, visually impaired persons, and the local community. Seminars and workshops for the local community will raise awareness of CVI, venous hypertension, and venous valve incompetence. The barrier-free Virtual Atlas of the Valves (VALV) web tool will provide a global repository for knowledge sharing, including tactile graphics of valvular tissue macro- and micro-anatomy for the visually impaired. The embossed tactile graphics from VALV will aid in providing additional accessible educational materials, enabling active learning by the visually impaired through their senses of touch. 

This CAREER project focuses on the structural-mechanical aspects of the venous valve tissues. The PI aims to determine, for the first time, the biaxial, nonlinear, and viscoelastic mechanical properties of venous valve leaflet, sinus and adjacent vein tissues, as well as biochemical quantification of venous valve extracellular matrix (ECM) constituents, collagen fiber orientation, and ECM morphology. Experimental structural-mechanical results will be incorporated into viscoelastic and structural-based constitutive models. Collectively, results will provide a much-needed comprehensive basis for understanding venous valve physiology, pathology, and for the advancement of both palliative and restorative therapies, including pharmacological, surgical, and rehabilitation interventions to combat CVI.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is a debilitating vascular disease with a prevalence estimated to be twice as high in women; risk increases with pregnancy, age, and occupations involving standing. CVI is attributed foremost to venous valve incompetence (i.e., the loss of function of venous valves). CVI is considered a disabling condition by the US Social Security Administration, however, increasing prevalence has not been met with commensurate increases in rehabilitation research. 

Venous valves are both anatomically and mechanically distinct from the four heart valves, distributed strategically, and in large number, throughout the veins to prevent retrograde flow. While superficially similar to heart valves, the scarce data available from a very limited number of studies suggest that venous valves exhibit compositional, structural and mechanical differences. Thus it is striking that the basic biomechanics of venous valve tissues has received little attention. Not even a uniaxial stress-strain curve, let alone biaxial characterization of tissue anisotropy, exists. This project focuses on the structural-mechanical aspects of the venous valve tissues. A brief project outcome is listed as follows:

The PI and her research group have determined, for the first time, the biaxial, nonlinear, and viscoelastic mechanical properties of venous valve leaflet, sinus and adjacent vein tissues, as well as biochemical quantification of venous valve extracellular matrix (ECM) constituents, collagen fiber orientation, and ECM morphology. 

Experimental structural-mechanical results were incorporated into viscoelastic and structural-based constitutive models. 
Results had provided a much-needed comprehensive basis for understanding venous valve physiology, pathology, and for the advancement of both palliative and restorative therapies, including pharmacological, surgical, and rehabilitation interventions to combat CVI.

In summary, this project has the potential to transform not only the basic science understanding of the physiological structure-function correlates of venous valves, but also to serve as a springboard for innovation, informing approaches to the treatment of CVI, by way of providing, for the first time, a detailed compositional, structural and biaxial mechanical characterization of venous valve leaflet, sinus, and associated vein tissues. The broader vision for the proposed research is that it will culminate in synergistic activities between experimental and clinical efforts aimed at a breakthrough in clinical treatments of damaged venous valve tissue and quality of life improvement.

This project provides a comprehensive and fundamental knowledge base of the micro-anatomy and micromechanical interactions of venous valve tissues. This new knowledge of venous valve leaflet behavior contributes decisively to basic venous physiology, and it is critically important to the development of novel approaches to the prevention, management, rehabilitation and repair of venous valve incompetence in CVI, such as prosthetic, and tissue-engineered venous valve replacements, surgical reconstruction techniques, design of calf muscle exercise regimens for the prevention and treatment of CVI, catheter designs for minimal venous valve damage in thrombectomy, and designing compression therapies to improve venous function in CVI and pregnancy. Thus, this research makes important contributions to fields within health care, science, engineering, and society as a whole. The PI and her research group had worked with the local NC Biotechnology Center to transfer the outcomes of this project outside of the academic community. Through presentations to local companies in the Research Triangle Park, this experience not only helps advertise these outcomes to companies in the field of tissue engineering, but also receives feedback on the impact of published experimental data to the technology development. 


Last Modified: 01/26/2023
Modified by: Shadow Huang
